title: Reading sporting director Mark Bowen denies making himself manager
text:
Mark Bowen has come out and denied claims that he basically appointed himself as Reading's new manager, following the departure of Jose Gomes.

As reported by Sportsmail, Bowen was involved in the recruitment process to find a new manager for the struggling Championship club, before it was announced that he himself would be taking over at the helm.

The 55-year-old, who has never previously managed a club on a permanent basis, was appointed as Reading's sporting director in August and previously worked for the club as a technical consultant.

Mark Bowen (left) has denied giving himself the job as first team manager of Reading

After details emerged of Bowen's involvement in recruitment, the Welshman has come out to reaffirm the role was given to him, and not taken.

'I've been a player and a coach for 40 years and I saw my reputation getting burned away in a matter of minutes,' Bowen told Sky Sports.

'I was the sporting director. I had no say whatsoever in Jose Gomes' dismissal.

Bowen says he was assessing candidates to replace the recently departed Jose Gomes

'I was informed by the board eight days ago that the decision had been made and to get on with the process of identifying managerial candidates, which I proceeded to.

'As the week went on, I spoke to two or three of them [candidates] and was going through that process.

'It got to the weekend and I got a phone call from the owner saying that he had had a think about things and wanted to know if I could take on the job. I didn't think twice.

'I know the club and I know the players. I think we're in a false position. It took me two seconds to say yes,' Bowen added.

Reading are currently in 22nd place in the Championship having won just two of their eleven league games so far this season.

Despite having not managed Bowen has experience as assistant with Southampton and others

Bowen was assistant manager of Southampton; a position that he also held at Stoke, QPR, Fulham, Manchester City, Blackburn and Birmingham. He also had a lengthy spell as assistant manager of Wales at the start of his coaching career.

As a player Bowen won the UEFA Cup with Tottenham in 1984 and also represented Norwich, West Ham and Charlton. He was capped by Wales on 41 occasions.
description: Mark Bowen has come out and denied claims that he basically appointed himself as Reading's new manager, following the departure of Jose Gomes.
